channel.name: Deploy fails when initializing a Struct state

messages.content: If your other question is correct and a UInt32 is more than 1 field, then this won’t work because you have more than 8 fields in state.  Not sure if that’s what this error is though.
I’m not sure though,  I think the only field on a uint is “value”, so it should just be 1 field?
uint32 is less than 1 field; also uint64, afaik field is like 255/256 bits so you could have uint256? dont quote me on this but cc @gregor
you simply have too much state, your votes struct gets converted toFields and ends up using 4 state fields
That stupid untyped constructor again
ah damn it inherits the CircuitValue constructor 😮
Sadly generic constructor and static methods are not possible in TS
unsure what you mean specifically, i know class level generics are not available for static methods, but what exactly is the problem here? i’d be happy to assist with my limited TS knowledge
Yep, that is what I assumed, but even after reducing the state (not shown in the question), the problem remained. Will try using  .from() as suggested.
On the other side, tahnks for confirming that structs are not packed into a Field even if 4 32 bit ints should be able to go into a 256 bits Field.
Thanks, will try this.

The size of data is irrelevant when it comes to counting fields.  In this case, it's true that 4 UInt32 is 4 fields.  But 4 Int64 would be 8 fields, because there is a `magnitude` and a `sign`.  8 Bools are each one bit, but it's still 8 fields.  I don't think packing and unpacking bits can be done in an arithmetic circuit, but of course that's not my specialty.  My point is using the default datatypes, you must simply count the length of `toFields`, which in the case of UInt32 is 1.
Packing could be done fwiw, and it's a good resource to squeeze out a bit more on chain state
Yes I get that, thanks !
Thanks for confirming it. I had doubts about if it will be doable inside a @method. I opened another question with how to do the packing ...

I'd like to get more practice with this.  I will review your comment in the other thread and try with some other custom types.  I have a couple more weeks to sprint on cohort 1, but after that I should have time to explore more.

Is there a reason why a generic packing solution wouldn't be packaged with snarky eventually, or why an additional package couldn't become a widely adopted standard lib?  Just that no one has built it yet?   Or is the speed slowdown just insanely slow?

e.g. in Mario's example, a struct consisting of 4 UInt32s goes on chain, shouldn't that struct's `toFields` method pack the uints into one field by default?  Could this be done by a package extending `Struct`?
Yes, I fully agree 🙂 I think a pack/unpack lib for structs to/from Field would be quite useful
In my case I have 6 UInt32 that would be possible to pack into a single Field, and now it takes  6 of the 8 possible state vars.

I thought about the same after writing my comment. A lib to do that - sure!
Doing automatically - not sure at all. For example, on chain state preconditions are per field element. Packing multiple states into one means that those preconditions become linked - a user who wants to restrict one value always has to have a valid precondition for the other values as well. This could make concurrency hard in some zkApps.
A lib for doing that would be just what is neded. Not automatically , no. Because as you mentioned in the other thread you have to prove the packing and unpacking.
No pun intended, but concurrency is already HARD in zkapps 🙂

That's right, I remember now.  It's easy to pack, but you can't unpack without knowing every input and verifying the computation like you said.  Something like allocating 4 equal-size chunks with some delimiter and referencing just by indices doesn't work.

But in many cases there will be something like this voting example.  The only problem with linking the preconditions here is it makes it tough to process votes async.  By the way - is that also true of using the struct, or can individual elements of the struct have different preconditions?
Well , I dispatch and action on sendVote() (where I just validate the vote is valid, no double voting, etc) and then use a reducer to collect votes. That solves the concurrency problem in my view.
Using recursive proofs may be the right solution, but is too much for my current knowledge 😦
Could you share the action/reducer code?
Yes, maybe on DM ? So we dont overflow this thread ...

> is that also true of using the struct, or can individual elements of the struct have different preconditions
they can have different preconditions! the protocol doesn't know about structs, only about 8 field elements of on-chain state. Structs are an abstraction at the SnarkyJS layer

So I'm thinking the most useful thing would be a packed value on chain that could be read by anyone to hydrate a local copy of the smart contract.  If you can't unpack the value it loses a lot of usefulness, and maybe is strictly worse than a poseidon hash.
I mean packing doesn't lose information so it seems more useful than a hash
I'll have to play with it more.  In my mental model, I'm concerned that you could unpack a value into a different datatype than it was packed into, and attack a contract like that.
Maybe that's not a useful angle.  But I'm wondering if you could add an authentication tag which says what the packed types are, and that has to be valid to be unpacked.
I think it's fine to have the type description off chain, i.e. in the code
If your snarkyjs code knows how to interpret the on-chain state, that's enough. For most zkApps the linking of preconditions also shouldn't be a problem

> In my mental model, I'm concerned that you could unpack a value into a different datatype than it was packed into, and attack a contract like that.
If the unpacking is done in the circuit, there's no way to unpack it differently, also in a circuit
Datatypes like UInt32 also have constraints attached to them, like that their field element fits in 32 bits, so the prover also can't cheat about that

Ok!

> For most zkApps the linking of preconditions also shouldn't be a problem

I strongly agree with this.
I'm interested what @maht0rz thinks about that statement? He might have the best understanding of common zkapp requirements.
wdym by linking preconditions?

For example in the voting app, will people design an app where the votes for are updated by one process and the votes against will be updated by a different process?  Or if you packed votes for and votes against into the same data?  Should a user be able to assertEquals one piece of state and not the other?
I imagine that in the specific case where a dev designed the app using a `Struct`, they really intend to know the whole state of the struct at a time, not bits and pieces.
i dont think i follow, sorry 😅

2 `Field`s can have independent preconditions, so for example each one can be updated once per block.  1 `PackedTuple` representing both base fields can only have a joint precondition, so for example the tuple can only be updated once per block.

In practice, I'm suggesting that zkapp devs are likely to add preconditions to all of their state at the same time, especially _related_ state as in a `Struct` type.  So it's not a practical difference between one precondition and two, it's only an academic one.
I only understand half the things people say about zk.  I feel like I'm doing pretty well!
No worries if it still doesn't make sense.  I think I'll prototype something and see how it works.
yep now i get it, sounds fair
